item.title: By: andrew
item.dc:creator: andrew
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/mysql/mysql-with-windows-server-2008-r2-failover-clustering#comment-546">Ryan</a>.
The advantage of using binaries on the shared storage is that you can be confident that the exact same version of the MySQL software will be used, if you were using local copies then you'd need to ensure that each had the same version of MySQL. The referenced white paper does describe how to update the service. Note that the paper is based on MySQL 5.5 but as far as I'm aware it should translate easily enough to MySQL 5.6.
Andrew.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Ryan.

The advantage of using binaries on the shared storage is that you can be confident that the exact same version of the MySQL software will be used, if you were using local copies then you’d need to ensure that each had the same version of MySQL. The referenced white paper does describe how to update the service. Note that the paper is based on MySQL 5.5 but as far as I’m aware it should translate easily enough to MySQL 5.6.

Andrew.

item.title: By: Ryan
item.dc:creator: Ryan
item.description:
What is the point of copying and updating the basedir to "basedir=”F:/MySQL Server 5.5”" ?
The service has the hardcoded path below. If I set the basedir to my iscsi path of F:/MySQL Server 5.5, the service won't start. Since mysql is installed on both servers, what is the point of putting the binaries on shared storage where they could just be accessed locally? Is it needed for the failover cluster? If so, does the service need to be modified?
---
"C:/MySQL/MySQL Server 5.6/binmysqld" --defaults-file="C:MySQLmy.ini" MySQL

item.title: By: andrew
item.dc:creator: andrew
item.content:encoded:
In reply to kalyan.

It looks like you’re trying to connect from a user/host combination that isn’t allowed – try this (substituting your username and host IP)…

mysql> grant all on *.* to ‘username’@’192.168.1.23’;
